summary: This is an FBI investigative update dated August 27, 2019, covering multiple active investigations related to Jeffrey Epstein. It details a court hearing to dismiss charges against Epstein, victim outreach, ongoing digital evidence reviews from seized devices, and updates on related death and public corruption investigations.

events.title: Court Hearing to Dismiss Epstein Charges
events.description: A court hearing took place in SDNY to formally drop charges against Jeffrey Epstein. Twenty-three victims were present, with many providing statements. The judge deferred a decision.

events.title: Post-Hearing Victim Conference
events.description: Following the hearing, the USAO held a conference with victims, attended by FBI NY personnel and SDNY prosecutors, to express continued commitment to the investigation.

events.title: Processing of CO Michael Thomas's Phone
events.description: FBI NY processed Correctional Officer Michael Thomas's cell phone as part of the death investigation and began a digital review.

events.title: Subpoena Served at Hutchinson Motel
events.description: FBI NY served a subpoena at the Hutchinson Motel in the Bronx for records pertaining to an individual and a correctional officer as part of a Color of Law investigation.

events.title: Shift of COs Thomas and Tovas
events.description: Correctional Officers Michael Thomas and Novel Tovas were on shift from 1600 to 0000, a period relevant to the death investigation of Jeffrey Epstein.

keyFacts: A court hearing was held on August 27, 2019, to formally drop charges against Jeffrey Epstein, with 23 victims present and providing statements.
FBI NY was actively reviewing digital evidence from three cell phones and planned to obtain warrants to examine 20 computers seized from LSJ, with imaging anticipated by mid-September 2019.

As part of the death investigation, FBI NY processed CO Michael Thomas's cell phone; Thomas had previously requested an attorney who cited potential criminal culpability regarding falsifying documents.
FBI NY served a subpoena at the Hutchinson Motel in the Bronx and canvassed a pizza establishment for surveillance footage as part of a Color of Law investigation.
The document references an individual described as a 'serial complainant' in a public corruption investigation, with most prior complaints being unfounded.
